Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I was hunched over my laptop, sweat prickling my neck as frantic Slack messages poured in. The production outage was my fault—a bug in my code had locked out thousands of users. My manager’s voice echoed in my head: “We need you on this, now.” But I was standing in the middle of the polling station, ballot envelope in hand, when the poll worker frowned and pointed out the smudged signature. “Please re-sign here, or your vote might not count,” she said gently. My phone buzzed again: “Are you there? We need a fix ASAP.” I felt torn in two. As a developer, I was expected to drop everything and restore the service. As a voter, I was supposed to follow every instruction to ensure my ballot was valid. My mind raced—if I left the line to troubleshoot, I might lose my chance to vote. If I stayed, the outage would drag on, and customers would keep calling. My hands shook as I stared at the pen, the envelope, and my phone, caught between two worlds demanding all of me at once.
